bestBHT.bht: Jesus, in a hypothetical argument, assumes that he casts out demons by Beelzebub to reveal the irrationality of such a belief. He challenges the Pharisees by asking about their own followers who claim to cast out demons, suggesting that even they would find it illogical to attribute the expulsion of evil spirits to Satan. This argument allows Jesus to dismantle their accusation against him and highlight the inconsistency of their reasoning.

Archibald T. Robertson: A Greek condition deals only with the statement, not with the actual facts.
For sake of argument, Jesus here assumes that he casts out demons by Beelzebub.
The conclusion is a reductio ad absurdum.
John Gill: By whom do your sons cast them out? by whose help? or in whose name? why should they ascribe the ejection of devils by Christ, to a diabolical assistance?"
Therefore shall they be your judges.

bhtAttempts.bht: According to one interpretation, Jesus presents a hypothetical scenario in Luke 11:19 where he assumes that he casts out demons by Beelzebub. This is not a factual statement but rather an argument to expose the absurdity of such a belief. By questioning the Pharisees about their own followers who claim to cast out demons, Jesus challenges them to consider whether it is logical to attribute the expulsion of evil spirits to Satan. In doing so, Jesus implies that their own disciples would denounce this reasoning, thereby refuting their accusation against him.

Jesus, in Luke 11:19, engages in a hypothetical argument, assuming that he casts out demons by Beelzebub, to expose the illogicality of such a notion. By questioning the Pharisees about their own followers who claim to have the power to cast out demons, Jesus challenges them to consider whether it is reasonable to attribute the expulsion of evil spirits to Satan. Essentially, Jesus implies that their own disciples would criticize this reasoning, thus undermining their accusation against him.

Jesus presents a hypothetical scenario where he assumes that he casts out demons by Beelzebub, not as a factual statement, but as a means to expose the folly of such a belief. By asking the Pharisees about their own followers who claim to cast out demons, Jesus prompts them to consider whether it is reasonable to attribute the expulsion of evil spirits to Satan. This implies that their own disciples would find this reasoning problematic, undermining their accusation against Jesus.

Jesus presents a hypothetical scenario in which he assumes that he casts out demons by Beelzebub. By doing so, he aims to demonstrate the absurdity of such a belief. He challenges the Pharisees by asking them about their own followers who claim to cast out demons, implying that even they would find it illogical to attribute the expulsion of evil spirits to Satan. In essence, Jesus uses this argument to refute the accusation against him and prove the inconsistency of their reasoning.

Jesus, in a hypothetical argument, assumes that he casts out demons by Beelzebub to reveal the irrationality of such a belief. He challenges the Pharisees by asking about their own followers who claim to cast out demons, suggesting that even they would find it illogical to attribute the expulsion of evil spirits to Satan. This argument allows Jesus to dismantle their accusation against him and highlight the inconsistency of their reasoning.
